Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2015 10:36PM GrammyR wrote: tanganchris- Yes it is possible. I am living proof . My neurooathy in my feet progressively worsened post chemo. 18 months later I suddenly could not move my ankles and was hospitalized w/suspected Guillien Barre Syndrome or MS. After several months and several new neurologist I was wearing leg braces and had trouble walking . A new group of neurolgist then said it was related to effects of chemo- specifically Taxol. I had to quit my nursing job and retire early at age 60. I wore leg braces for 5 years. Finally about a year ago my leg felt stronger deslite foot drop and continuing neuropathy. I can now walk w/out a cane even, rather slower than I would like but happy that I can do some gardening and get around more. Still have not been able to ride a bike like I used to for years. I am blessed to have two beautiful grandchildren who visit a lot and keep me active. I occasionally use a pain pill when my feet get bad at night but have learned to live w/it. There are various meds that are supposed to help neuropathy but none worked for me.Going in tbe swimming pool was best therapy, taking the weight off the legs. I am also taking Amitryptyline at bedtime for restless leg syndrome. It helps some. So please go see a neurologist and explore treatments.My prayers that it will clear up for you very soon. Hugs Rene

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2013 03:06PM GrammyR wrote: Steroid w/chemo reduce the chance of having a bad reaction however they come along w/their own set of side effects which are not so cool. One is insomnia ( which is likely what happened here ) I think I only had them a right before chemo for 2-3 days so less chance of long term side effects. Most women gain some weight during chemo not lose as I had thought. Steroids can also temporarily increase your blood sugar. Used for daily longer than a few weeks they can cause cataracts ( which I now have ) and cause a temporary pimply looking rash ( only on some people- mine was all over my back ) and large amount of weight gain ( 20 lbs for me but I lost most it w/much work  ) and mood swinges. The very short time you take them for chemo will likely not give you long term effcts. But best to talk to your Onc to be sure. Hugs going out to you.

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2013 06:46PM GrammyR wrote: fredntan my response is NO-NO-NO on the HRT. I was in early menopause at age 48 not sleeping, depressed and so skinny my weight was very hard to maintain. My mom died at age 68 heart attcak and grandmothers both has bad osteoporosis. HRT was supposed to help prevent that. Well at age 58 I was diagnosed Stage 2b hormonal BC. No ca history in my family at all. Of course I stopped all hormones. Now at 65 my BC has returned, again ER pos hormonal ( how come as I was long past menopause) Onc says other glands like adrenals put out hormones even if ovaries are not. So back to Tamoxifen and now radiation. So please send out the word to all women ( stay away from HRT) it may save your life.

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2013 06:08PM GrammyR wrote: Lymphoma is a totally different. Kind of cancer so am sure you are meaning Lymphodema which is a complication of lymph node removals after mastectomy. I has 22 nodes removed with just one being positive for cancer. I had terrible burning under my arm and under the incision area of the breast. Part of my underarm skin is still numb today 6 years later .I would suspect yours is due to some nerve damage under the arm as mine was.For the surgeon to be successful at removing a bunch of lymph nodes it is almost impossible to not have some nerves be pushed around during this surgery. I think your surgeon would tell you it can take a long time for nerves to heal. Have you asked yours about this?. Did you get some Physical Therapy after surgery. That may help or even exercise of the arm at home. I now have a problem w/shoulder pain now and therapy was suggested.

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2014 03:00PM GrammyR wrote: MelissaDall- as I said it helps the surgeon know where to cut. What I meant  was that it has no medicinal value. I had a full mastectomy and lymph nodes surgically removed 2006. They did not use this marker back then but the day of surgery I wss injected into my breast multiple times  with a type of blue dye. This apparently "lit up " the cancerous cells.  There happened to be more than he had initially thought. It was not until  6 years later that my other breast got a biopsy done. That is when I refused the titanium marker.  I might add that I have suffered w/crippling neuropathy  and foot drop since getting Taxol chemo in 2006 and even had to wear leg braces (still do)  So please folks make them explain fully any and all SE of anything that will go in or on your body an allergic reaction only takes a second to cause anaphalaxis or a lifetime of SE.

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2013 05:15PM - edited Oct 5, 2013 05:28PM by GrammyR Law- I will go along w/others that caution that this is a marathon and not a sprint. Throwing everyyhing at you but the kitchen sink may or may not halt progression. My story is very similar ,benign lump that changed in 2 years to pos ER and also inverted (dimple) nipple. With a 2cm original lesion and pos lymph node /s this makes it impossible to stop but perhaps delay further spread and symptoms. PLEASE take some time off( even a week or two ) between treatments. Your body can only take so much of a hit. You had a lot of Taxol, the neuropathy has been extreme for me. Of course at the time of surgery you just want to get it all done and over with. I was 58 and in menopause supposedly . HRT to blame for mine I am sure but no Onc would ever confirm.this.I wish I had sued the drug company before the statute of limitations had run out. As others have mentiones too. It is still about quality of life for most of us. Doctors only like to quote statistics for being "alive " at 5 years. Either way, big hugs coming out to you. Hang in there and as they say " take some time to smell the roses". I feel impelled to say also that deferring on any kind of treatment is quitting This is the kind if BS every one trys to throw at us. Let them walk a day in your shoes before ever talking the talk.

I lay for an hour undressed while I waited to get these " dye  injections " .  I had no idea what for and it hurt like hell. My surgeon had told me he doubted I would need ANY nodes removed. Not sure if they still do it that way but cells were sent down to pathology while I was still on the op table.. It was over 5 hours. My poor fiancé was the last person still in the post op waiting room at the end of the day. Turned out a bunch of nodes removed and only the sentinel one was positive. The cyst on the other breast was also there back then and they assured me it was only a cyst.  I am not really looking forward to another mammo this year.

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2013 08:46PM GrammyR wrote: I am 65 w/return on BC. I was divorced (1st time) when my only child was 5  years old. The divorce was not my choice , so you see (Kay) I could not have a sibling for my son which I would have liked. Nothing to do w/ BC at the time. I remained single until 2 years after chemo at age 60.  I had known him 6 years and believe now I was just grateful he had stuck w/me thru it all. Ultimately it did not work out. I moved across country to be close to my 2 grandkids last year prior to finding out about BC being back. No regrets. I had the most beautiful small wedding ceremony the 2nd time around ( which was not the case for the 1st). My siblings are all overseas and I have not seen them for more than 13 years. As a nurse my whole life I never seemed to get time off or have the money to get back to UK. Now my goal is to get well enough to be able to travel and then that will be one regret I will not have anymore. I think God has his plan for us all mapped when we are born so everything happens for a reason. So I feel blessed to have made it this far and pray I can see my grandkids growup. So you see my bucket list is short.

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2014 03:37PM GrammyR wrote: Sunny2010- I feel for you as a lot of us have been subjected to similar events. I am blessed w /very fine  straight hair which was long and silky pre chemo days. I was 58 but still very vain . Ended up doing the scarf thing as Fl was way to hot for a wig. I have had some terrible cuts over the years and last year when my BC returned I decided to stop all coloring , go grey and get the occasional trim. My adorning red hair has taken amost a year and is 2/3 grey-white now. I have even had a few compliments from FB friends asking me what color was I using now as they thought I had gone blonde .ha..au natural , I replied. I have walked w/a cane and legs splint for over 6 years now but any day I can walk, drive and enjoy the outdoors w/ out pain is a blessing.  So you must have nice thick hair to even accomplish that " mushroom look " ...ha.  I have been lucky enough to meet a lovely retirement age stylist at one of those chain shops. She quit there as she is battling leumemia but likes to get out of the house some, so she actually comes to my home (and a few others ) to give us a trim and chat. So maybe enquire around near you there maybe someone like that. I don't even know who Michelle Williams is so maybe your stylist didn't either. Hugs coming your way.

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2013 08:55PM GrammyR wrote: Very long post to read thur but will try to respond. I had a biopsy just over a year ago in my left breast. I have already been thru BC treatment for right breast several years ago. I freaked out when the doctor doing the needle biopsy said I had to have the titanium marker inserted. They almost refused to do it as I told them I did want any metal left inside me. ( I am also very allergic and past 7 years one thing after) This left side had always been described as a " cyst". Anyway she agreed to remove the fluid and if it looked clear would not send it to the lab and NOT place a marker, Which is what she did. I was mostly concerned about irritation -inflammation a metal tip could react inside my breast. I am a retired RN and my experience w/titanium was it is the strongest metal there is. I am still bothered that she never sent the fluid off for pathology. Your marker should be viewable on xray and they could remove it. Question would be who would do it and who would pay for it. Could be done but costly. I might add that I have several surgical clips in my chest and under arm from my mastectomy that almost got identified as ca spread.

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2014 11:10PM - edited Dec 17, 2014 11:11PM by GrammyR    diana59 - Try to hang in there. My prayers come out to you. Shingles is one if the most painful conditions even when you are not on chemo. As a nurse I saw transplant patients who got it. Antiviral meds help to clear it but the pain can remain weeks after the rash is gone. Please ask for enough pain meds to get you through. Steroids do lesson inflammation but also increase risk of cancer cells multiplying so they are used very sparingly during chemo. The shingles vaccine has supposedly 14 times higher amount of live virus than the chicken pox vaccine that children get so I am undecided as to if I get it or not. The old soothing comfort for chicken pox is bathing in cornstarch and oatmeal bath. Perhaps an evening head wrap ( just a thought- messy I know ) Hugs. Rene
